and [[Marshal of France]]
(later Charles XIV of Sweden)}} {{familytree|border=0| | | | | | | |,|-|'| }} {{familytree|border=0| | | | |VASA|^|PONT |VASA=[[File:Arms of the French Empire3.svg|120px]]
[[Napoleon I of France|Napoleon I]]|PONT=
[[Ponte Corvo]]}} {{familytree/end}} [[File:Personal command-sign of the King of Sweden.svg|thumb|left|The personal command sign, for military use, of the King is a rendition of the emblazonment of the greater arms. Introduced by royal regulation in 1943, it has only been created once.]] The arms are supported by two lions with forked tails (''queue fourchée''), facing away from the shield and crowned with Royal Crowns. For centuries, the lion has been an important element in Swedish heraldry and especially for the State Coat of Arms. The shield may be surmounted by the Collar of the [[Order of Seraphim]], the foremost order in Sweden, and the highest honour the Swedish state can bestow on an individual.See sections 2 and 3, Lag No. 268 om Sveriges Riksvapen of April 29, 1982. Besides being the official national coat of arms, the greater coat of arms is also the personal coat of arms of the king, and as such he can decree its use as a personal coat of arms by other members of the [[House of Bernadotte|Royal House]], with the alterations and additions decided by him. [[Blazon]]: "The greater state arms consist of a head shield azure, quartered by a cross or with outbent arms, and an [[inescutcheon]] containing the dynastic arms of the Royal House. In the first and fourth fields three coronets or, placed two above one. In the second and third fields three sinisterbendwise streams argent, a lion crowned with an open crown or with armaments gules. The inescutcheon is party per pale the arms for the [[House of Vasa]] and the [[House of Bernadotte]]. The main shield is crowned by a royal crown and surrounded by the insignia of the [[Order of the Seraphim]]. Supported by two lions regardant or crowned, with parted tails and armaments gules, standing on a postament. All surrounded by hermine mantling crowned with a royal crown and tied up with tasseled strings or." ===Lesser version=== The lesser coat of arms is mainly used by the [[Government of Sweden]] and subordinate government authorities. As such it may be joined by insignias symbolising the activity of individual government agencies, following approval by the State Board of Heraldry. It is, for instance, embroidered on all [[Swedish police]] uniforms and in various coats of arms of the [[Swedish Armed Forces]]. Blazon: "Azure, with three coronets Or, ordered two above one." Crowned with a royal crown. The shield may also be surrounded by the insignias of the [[Order of the Seraphim]]." ===Royal Family=== {| class="wikitable" |- style="text-align:center;" ! Gästrikland]] |- style="text-align:center;" |[[File:Coat of arms of Princess Leonore, Duchess of Gutland.svg|120px]]||[[Princess Leonore, Duchess of Gotland]] |- style="text-align:center;" page.title: Coat of arms of the King of Spain

revision.comment: /* Ornamented versions of the historical royal coats of arms */
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2012}} {{Infobox coat of arms | image = Coat of Arms of Spanish Monarch.svg | image_width = 180 | armiger = [[Felipe VI of Spain|Felipe VI]] | year_adopted = 19 June 2014 | crest = [[Spanish Royal Crown]] | shield = [[Quartering (heraldry)|Quarterly]]: [[Coat of arms of Castile and León|Castile]], [[Coat of arms of Castile and León|León]], [[Crown of Aragon|Aragon]], and [[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarre]]; enté en point: [[Granada]]; inescutcheon [[National Emblem of France|Bourbon (Anjou Branch)]] | supporters = | orders = [[Order of the Golden Fleece]] | other_elements = | earlier_versions = ''[[Coat of arms of the King of Spain#Ornamented versions of the historical royal coats of arms|See below]]'' }} The '''coat of arms of the King of Spain''' is the [[heraldic symbol]] representing the monarch of Spain. The current version of the monarch's coat of arms was adopted in 2014 but is of much older origin. The arms marshal the arms of the former monarchs of [[Kingdom of Castile|Castille]], [[Kingdom of León|León]], [[Kingdom of Aragon|Aragon]], and [[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarre]]. Traditionally, coats of arms did not belong to a nation but to the monarch who would quarter his shield with territorial claims of his dynasty. Formerly, the Spanish monarch's arms were much more complex than they are today. It would feature the arms of the various territories of this dynasty. A simpler version of these arms, known as the ''lesser arms'', would also be used; This lesser arms were another set of arms within the centre of the full arms. During the later part of the Bourbon dynasty this would be quarterly Castille and Leon. In 1868, during the [[Provisional Government (1868-1871)|provisional government]] that followed the overthrow of Queen [[Isabella II]], an arms of ''national character'' was adopted; This 1868 arms created the present-day arrangement of elements in the shield. The "national arms" and "royal arms" would coexist after the restoration of the monarchy. In 1931, the royal arms was revised to incorporate what had been hitherto the "national arms" into the royal arms and to replace the former lesser arms of the King (i.e. quarterly Castille and Leon). The monarchy would later be abolished later that year. When don Juan Carlos, grandson of Alfonso XIII (the last king of Spain), was chosen to be the successor of General [[Francisco Franco]], the arms adopted for his use in 1971 as Prince of Spain was quarterly Castille, Leon, Aragon, and Navarre. The heraldic achievement also included the collar of the [[Order of the Golden Fleece]], the Cross of Burgundy and the yoke and bundle of arrows formerly used by the [[Catholic Monarchs]]; This would be the same arms he would use as King. Upon Felipe VI's ascension to the throne in 2014, the cross, yoke, and arrows would not be retained in the royal arms. ==Blazon== The [[blazon]]ing of the coat of arms of the King of Spain is set out in Royal Decree 527/2014, 20 June, an amendment to Title II of Spanish Royal Decree 1511/1977 adopting Flags, Standards, Guidons, Insignia and Emblems Regulation.{{cite web |url=http://www.boe.es/boe/dias/2014/06/21/pdfs/BOE-A-2014-6525.pdf |title=Real Decreto 527/2014, de 20 de junio, por el que se crea el Guión y el Estandarte de Su Majestad el Rey Felipe VI y se modifica el Reglamento de Banderas y Estandartes, Guiones, Insignias y Distintivos, aprobado por Real Decreto 1511/1977, de 21 de enero. |date=20 June 2014 |website= BOE Spanish Official Journal|series= |publisher= |location= |page= |pages= |at= |language= Spanish|trans-title=Royal Decree 527/2014 setting up the Guidon and Standard of HM King Felipe VI and amends Standards, Guidons, Insignia and Emblems Regulation, adopted on Royal Decree 1511/1977|accessdate=2014-06-21}} The coat of arms was adopted when King [[Felipe VI of Spain|Felipe VI]] was enthroned as King of Spain.{{cite web |url=http://www.heraldo.es/noticias/nacional/2014/06/19/felipe_cuenta_con_escudo_guion_propios_294797_305.html |title=Felipe VI ya cuenta con escudo y guión propios |language=Spanish |trans-title=Felipe VI has his own coat of arms and guidon |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= 2014-06-19|website=www.heraldo.es |publisher= |accessdate=2014-06-20}} The shield is divided into four quarters, blazoned as follows: *1st, [[gules]] a castle [[Or (heraldry)|or]], triple-embattled and voided gate and windows, with three towers each triple-turreted, of the field, masoned [[sable]] and ajoure [[azure (heraldry)|azure]], which is for [[Kingdom of Castile|Castile]]; *2nd, [[argent]] a lion [[rampant]] purpure crowned or, langued and armed, of the second, which is for [[Kingdom of León|León]]; *3rd, or, four pallets gules, which is for [[Crown of Aragon|Aragon]]; *4th, gules a cross, saltire and orle of chains linked together or, a centre point vert, which is for [[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarre]]; Argent enté en point, with a pomegranate proper seeded gules, supported, sculpted and leafed in two leaves vert, which is for [[Granada]]. Inescutcheon [[azure (heraldry)|azure]] [[bordure]] gules, three [[fleurs-de-lys]] or, which is for [[House of Bourbon|Bourbon-Anjou]]. All surrounded by the collar of the [[Order of the Golden Fleece|Golden Fleece]] and crowned with a crown of the same metal and precious stones, with eight rosettes, five visible, and eight pearls interspersed, closed at the top by eight diadems also adorned with pearls and surmounted by a cross on a globe, which is the royal crown of Spain.[http://www.casareal.es/sm_rey/armas-iden-idweb.html Coat of arms of His Majesty the King of Spain]. The Royal Household of the King of Spain. Retrieved 19 October 2011. In 1969, General [[Francisco Franco]] appointed [[Juan Carlos I of Spain|Juan Carlos I]] as his "successor to the Headship of the Spanish state with the title of King" but gave him the new title of [[Prince of Spain]] instead of the traditional title of [[Prince of Asturias]]. From 1971 to 1975, Juan Carlos as Prince of Spain used a coat of arms which was virtually identical to the one later adopted when he became King in 1975. Earlier coat of arms differed only that it featured the royal crown of a Crown Prince of Spain, the King's royal crown has eight half-arches of which five are visible, while the Prince's one has only four half-arches of which three are visible.{{es icon}} [http://www.armada.mde.es/ArmadaPortal/page/Portal/ArmadaEspannola/conocenos_historia/03_bandera_armada--14_miscelania--02_insignias_jefes_estado--05_juan_carlos_i_es ''Spanish Decree 814 of 22nd April 1971'']. Boletín Oficial del Estado, Official Gazette of the Spanish Government, no. 99. Retrieved 19 October 2011. Joined to the shield was the red saltire of [[Cross of Burgundy Flag|Burgundy]] and, to the dexter and sinister of the base point, the yoke gules in its natural position with ribbons, of the field, and the sheaf of five arrows gules with the arrowheads inverted and ribbons, of the field, which used to be the symbol of the [[Catholic Monarchs]] of Spain. Since June 2014, Juan Carlos's son, Felipe VI, has been using the same arms but without the cross of Burgundy, yoke and arrows.{{cite web |url=http://www.casareal.es/EN/FamiliaReal/rey/Paginas/rey_armas.aspx |title=Coat of arms of His Majesty King Juan Carlos |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= 2014-06-19|website=Spanish Royal Household Website |publisher= |accessdate=2014-06-20}} King Juan Carlos's arms include a red lion instead of the purple one displayed on the current version{{cite web |url=http://www.casareal.es/EN/FamiliaReal/ReyFelipe/Paginas/principe_armas.aspx |language= |title= Coat of arms of His Majesty the King|last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= 2014-06-19|website=Spanish Royal Household Website |publisher= |accessdate=2014-06-20}} == Variants ==
{| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan=4 | Variants of the coat of arms of the King of Spain |- |[[File:Coat of Arms of Spanish Monarch-Variant as Grand Master of the Order of Charles III.svg|center|217px]] |[[File:Coat of Arms of Spanish Monarch-Variant as Grand Master of the Order of Isabella the Catholic.svg|center|210px]] |[[File:Coat of Arms of Spanish Monarch-Variant as Grand Master of the Order of Saint Ferdinand.svg|center|224px]] |[[File:Coat of Arms of Spanish Monarch-Variant as Grand Master of the Order of Saint Hermenegild.svg|center|210px]] |- |Variant as Grand Master of the

of this order |Variant as Grand Master of the
[[Royal and Military Order of Saint Hermenegild|Order of Saint Hermenegild]]

of this order |- |}

page.title: Coat of arms of the Prince of Asturias

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} {{Infobox coat of arms | image = Coat of Arms of Leonor, Princess of Asturias.svg | image_width = 180 | armiger = [[Leonor, Princess of Asturias]] | year_adopted = 30 October 2015 | crest = [[Crown (heraldry)|Crown]] of the Princess of Asturias | shield = [[Quartering (heraldry)|Quarterly]]: [[Coat of arms of Castile and León|Castile]], [[Coat of arms of Castile and León|León]], [[Crown of Aragon|Aragon]], and [[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarre]]; ''enté en point'', [[Granada]]; [[inescutcheon]][[National Emblem of France|Bourbon (Anjou Branch)]]; the whole differenced by a [[Label (heraldry)|label]] [[azure (heraldry)|azure]]. | orders = [[Order of the Golden Fleece]] | earlier_versions = ''See below'' }} The [[blazon]] of the '''[[coat of arms]] of the [[Princess of Asturias]]''' is given by a Royal Decree 979 on 30 October 2015 which was an amendment of the Royal Decree 1511 dated [[Madrid]] 21 January 1977, which also created her guidon (military personal ensign) and her standard.{{cite web|title=Boletín Oficial del Estado|url=http://www.boe.es/boe/dias/2015/10/31/pdfs/BOE-A-2015-11729.pdf|accessdate=31 October 2015|language=Spanish}} ==Official blazon== The shield is divided into four quarters, blazoned as follows: *1st, [[Gules]] a castle three-towered [[Or (heraldry)|Or]], masoned [[Sable]] ajoure, (door and windows) [[Azure (heraldry)|Azure]], for [[Kingdom of Castile|Castile]]; *2nd, [[Argent]] a lion rampant Purpure crowned Or, armed Gules and crowned Or, for [[Kingdom of León|León]]; *3rd, Or four pallets Gules, for [[Crown of Aragon|Aragon]]; *4th, Gules a cross, saltire and orle of chains all linked Or, an emerald Proper, for [[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarre]]; *''Enté en point'', Argent a pomegranate Proper seeded Gules, supported, sculpted and leafed in two leaves [[Vert (heraldry)|Vert]], for [[Granada]]; *[[Inescutcheon]], Azure with three [[fleurs-de-lys]] Or, [[bordure]]d Gules, for [[House of Bourbon|Bourbon]]. The whole is differenced by a [[Label (heraldry)|label]] of three points Azure, the [[brisure|difference]] used by heirs apparent to the [[House of Habsburg|Spanish House of Habsburg]]. The shield is surmounted by a closed crown, which is a circle of gold, inset with precious stones of their colours, composed of eight rosettes of acanthus leaves, of which five are visible, interspersed by pearls in their colour, issuing from which are four pearl diadems, of which three are visible, which converge in a blue orb, with gold semi-meridian and equator, surmounted by a gold cross, the crown lined with red and surrounded by the collar of the [[Order of the Golden Fleece|Golden Fleece]]. ==History== {| width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" border="1" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 0.5em 1em 0.5em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |- | {| width = "100%" border = 1 border="1" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 0.5em 1em 0.5em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |- |colspan = "3" bgcolor = "#ccccff" align="center"|''' Historical Arms of Princes and Princesses of Asturias''' |- !width = "35%"|Arms !width = "20%"|Dates !width = "45%"|Details |- |
[[File:Coat of Arms of the Heir of the Crown of Castile (1230-1284).svg|130px]] [[File:Coat of Arms of the Heir of the Crown of Castile (1284-1390).svg|130px]] [[File:Coat of Arms of the Prince of Asturias (1390-15th Century).svg|130px]]
||1388–1468||The arms used in the 13th and 14th century by the Prince of Asturias, and the others heirs apparent to the [[Crown of Castile|Castilian]] Throne before the title was adopted, were the [[Undifferenced arms|undifferenced Royal Arms]]. However, the '' [[Infante]]s'' used differenced arms.Francisco Olmos, José María de [http://www.ucm.es/info/documen/articulos/art_tercera/art_chema.pdf Las primeras acuñaciones del príncipe Felipe de España (1554–1556): Soberano de Milán Nápoles e Inglaterra. The First Coins of Prince Felipe of Spain (1554–1556): Sovereign of Milan, Naples and England. pp.165–166] {{es icon}}Rodríguez de Maribona, Manuel [http://www.abc.es/informacion/boda/biografia_principe/07f.asp Las armas del Príncipe de Asturias – ABC]. {{es icon}} Accessed 2009-05-28. |- |
[[File:Coat of Arms of Isabella of Castile as Princess of Asturias (with crest).svg|150px]] [[File:Coat of Arms of Isabella of Castile as Princess of Asturias.svg|150px]]|| 1468–1474|| [[Isabella I of Castile|Princess Isabella]] (Isabella I as Queen of Castile) used the undifferenced Castilian Royal Arms and added the [[Eagle (heraldry)#Eagle of Saint John|Saint John the ''Evangelist'''s Eagle]], an [[Eagle (heraldry)|eagle "displayed"]] as single [[supporter]]. In 1473 the Princess Isabella's seal bearing her arms without crest and the St John the ''Evangelist'''s Eagle.{{cite book |last= |first= |title=Isabel la Católica en la Real Academia de la Historia |year=2004 |publisher= Real Academia de la Historia |location=Madrid |page=72|ISBN=84-95983-54-0 }}Princess of Isabella's coat of arms with crest: {{cite journal | last1 =García-Menacho Osset | first1 =Eduardo |date = | year =2010 | title =El origen militar de los símbolos de España. El escudo de España|trans-title=Military Origin of Symbols of Spain. The Coat of Arms of Spain| journal =Revista de Historia Militar | issue =Extra | series = |page=387 | location = | publisher =Instituto de Historia y Cultura Militar | language =Spanish | issn = 0482-5748}} |- |
[[File:Coat of Arms of John of Aragon and Castile, Prince of Asturias and Girona (with crest).svg|150px]] [[File:Coat of Arms of John of Aragon and Castile, Prince of Asturias and Girona.svg|150px]]|| 1478–1497||On the tomb of [[John, Prince of Asturias]] and [[Prince of Girona|Girona]] in [[Ávila, Spain#Real Monasterio de Santo Tomás|St Thomas's Royal Monastery]], sculpted by [[Domenico Fancelli]], is shown the undifferenced Catholic Monarchs's coat of arms without crest supported by the St John the ''Evangelist'''s Eagle and two [[Putto|putti]] frequently used as sculptural decoration but not heraldic supporters in Spanish royal heraldry.[http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Avila_-_Real_Monasterio_de_Santo_Tomas_21.JPG Image of the coat of arms on Prince John's tomb]. |- |align="center" colspan="2"| 1506–1516||When the [[House of Habsburg]] inherited the Crowns of Castile and Aragon marks of [[Cadency]] – a [[label (heraldry)|label]] of three points – were added to the heirs apparent's arms, as was usual in the heraldry of many European monarchies. Prince [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles]] (Charles I as King of Spain and Charles V as Holy Roman Emperor) used his father's arms – ''A quartered shield, depicting [[Austria]], new [[Burgundy (region)|Burgundy]], old Burgundy, [[Duchy of Brabant|Brabant]] and [[Coat of arms of Flanders|Flanders]] on an escutcheon'' – with a label argent. These arms weren’t used as Prince of Asturias because Prince Charles didn’t add the arms of Castile and Aragon.{{cite book |last= Menéndez-Pidal De Navascués |first= Faustino |title=El Escudo de España |year=2004 |publisher= Real Academia Matritense de Heráldica y Genealogía |location=Madrid |pages=191–192|ISBN=84-88833-02-4 }} |- |
[[File:Coat of Arms of Philip of Austria, Prince of Asturias-Azur Label (1527-1554).svg|border|150px]] [[File:Coat of Arms of Philip of Austria, Prince of Asturias-Argen Label (1527-1554).svg|border|150px]]
||1528–1556|| Prince [[Philip II of Spain|Philip]] (Philip II as King of Spain and Philip I of Portugal) used his father's arms differenced with a label argent or azure. The Prince Philip's arms are shown on many Prince's [[armour]]s. Now these armours have been kept at the Royal Armoury in the [[Royal Palace of Madrid]]. Sometimes, Philip also used the undifferenced arms of his father. |- |
[[File:Coat of Arms of the Prince of Asturias-Azur Label (1560-1578).svg|border|150px]] [[File:Coat of Arms of the Prince of Asturias-Argen Label (1560-1578).svg|border|150px]]
||1560–1568|| In 1568 Prince [[Carlos, Prince of Asturias|Carlos]], the eldest son of Philip II, died and an [[Ambrosio Morales]]'s report for the Prince's [[sepulchre]] said his arms were the Royal Arms but with "''a label azure with its three short points".'' Prince Carlos also used the royal arms differenced with a label argent. |- |
[[File:Coat of Arms of Philip of Austria, Prince of Asturias-Argen Label Wavy Variant (1580-1598).svg|border|180px]]
||1584–1598|| Prince [[Philip III of Spain|Philip]] (Philip III as King of Spain and Philip II of Portugal) sometimes used a new label argent variant wavy azure. |- |
[[File:Coat of Arms of the Prince of Asturias-Azur Label (1580-1665).svg|border|150px]] [[File:Coat of Arms of the Prince of Asturias-Argen Label (1580-1665).svg|border|150px]]
||1608–1665||The eldest son of Philip III, Prince [[Philip IV of Spain|Philip]] (Philip IV as King of Spain and Philip III of Portugal), used the Royal Arms with label argent or azure. Philip's son, Prince [[Balthasar Charles, Prince of Asturias|Balthasar Charles]] also bore the same differences. |- |
[[File:Coat of Arms of the Prince of Asturias (1700-1761)-Version with Golden Fleece and Holy Spirit Collars.svg|border|150px]]
[[File:Coat of Arms of the Prince of Asturias (1761-1868 and 1874-1931)-Golden Fleece and Order of Charles III Variant.svg|border|150px]]
||1707–1761
1761–1931|| The shields of the [[House of Bourbon]]'s heirs apparent hardly ever depicted differences. [[Cronista Rey de Armas|Chronicler King of Arms]] Juan José Vilar y Psayla (1830–1894) said the arms of the Prince of Asturias were differentiated by a crown of four-half-arches, the Spanish monarch's crown has eight-half-arches since the reign of [[Philip V of Spain|Philip V]] (1700–1746). |- |align="center" colspan="2"|1971-1975
''1977-2001
(De facto without use)''[http://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/es%5Epri71.html Standard of the Heir Prince 1971-1975, possibly also 1982-2001 (Spain). [[Flags of the World|FOTW]]]. Retrieved 18 February 2016.||{{further|Coat of arms of the Prince of Spain}} |- |
[[File:Coat of Arms of Felipe, Prince of Asturias (2001-2014).svg|border|150px]]
||2001–2014|| The coat of arms used by the future King [[Felipe VI of Spain|Felipe VI]] as Prince of Asturias had the [[Coat of Arms of the King of Spain|royal arms of Spain]] differenced by a label of three points Azure, this recovered difference has been used by heirs apparent to the Spanish House of Habsburg. Prince Felipe's coat of arms was adopted by the Royal Decree 284 dated Madrid 16 March 2001, which also created his Guidon and Standard.{{cite web|title=Boletín Oficical del Estado|url=http://www.boe.es/buscar/doc.php?id=BOE-A-2001-5302|accessdate=1 November 2015|language=Spanish}} |- |} |} ==See also== *[[Coat of arms of the King of Spain]] *[[Coat of arms of the Prince of Spain]] *[[Coat of arms of Spain]] *[[Royal Standard of Spain]] *[[Coat of arms of the Prince of Wales]] ==Notes== *On sepulchres of Habsburg Princes of Asturias who didn't ascend to the throne their coats of arms are the undifferenced Lesser Royal Arms (''Quarterly, 1 and 4 [[Kingdom of Castile|Castile]], 2 and 3 [[Kingdom of León|León]]''), with a crown closed with four-half-arches in crest. The Pantheon of the Princes of the [[El Escorial|Royal Seat of El Escorial]] was completed in 1888, in the nineteenth century the heir to the Spanish throne used Royal Arms differentiated by a crown of four-half-arches.{{cite AV media |people=Bazhe |year= |title=Royal Pantheon El Escorial |trans-title= |medium= |language= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KVf7LlonKyw |accessdate=3 January 2012 |archiveurl= |archivedate= |format= |time= 8:12publisher=You Tube |location= |id= |isbn= |oclc= |quote= |ref= }} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Spanish coat of arms}} [[Category:Personal coats of arms|Prince of Asturias]] [[Category:Spanish coats of arms|Prince of Asturias]] [[Category:Spanish monarchy]] [[Category:Princes of Asturias]] [[Category:Coats of arms with crowns|Asturias, Prince]] [[Category:Coats of arms with buildings|Asturias, Prince]] [[Category:Coats of arms with chains|Asturias, Prince]] [[Category:Coats of arms with lions|Asturias, Prince]] [[Category:Coats of arms with fleurs de lis|Asturias, Prince]] [[Category:Coats of arms with the Golden Fleece|Asturias, Prince]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Women of the Byzantine Empire]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
'''Domentzia''' was a name shared by the mother of the [[List of Byzantine emperors|Byzantine emperor]] [[Phocas]] (r. 602–610), and a daughter of the same emperor, likely named after her paternal grandmother.<ref name=PLRE409>Martindale, Jones & Morris (1992), p. 409</ref>
== Name == The mother is only named by [[John of Antioch (chronicler)|John of Antioch]], who renders her name in [[Greek language|Greek]] as "Dysmenziane" (Δυσμενζιανή). All other occurrences of the name refer to the daughter. The more familiar form "Domentzia" (Δομεντζία) is given by [[Theophanes the Confessor]]. [[Anastasius Bibliothecarius]], who translated the work of Theophanes to [[Latin]], renders the name "Domnentzia". The later historian [[Joannes Zonaras]] gives the name as "Domnentia" (Δομνεντία), while [[Nikephoros Kallistos Xanthopoulos]] gives her name as "Dysmenziane", indicating that both women used the same name.<ref name=PLRE409/>
== Mother of Phocas ==
Phocas and his family were likely of [[Thraco-Roman]] origin.<ref name=Bury197>Bury (2009), p. 197</ref> The husband of the elder Domentzia is unknown.She had three known sons: Phocas, [[Comentiolus (brother of Phocas)|Comentiolus]]<ref name=PLRE326>Martindale, Jones & Morris (1992), p. 326</ref> and [[Domentziolus (brother of Phocas)|Domentziolus]]. The latter seems to have been ''[[magister officiorum]]'' by 610.<ref name=Bury201>Bury (2009), p. 201</ref> A grandson, also named [[Domentziolus (nephew of Phocas)|Domentziolus]], was granted the title of ''[[curopalates]]'' on the ascension of Phocas to the throne in 602.<ref name=Bury199>Bury (2009), p. 199</ref>
== Daughter of Phocas ==
The younger Domentzia was a daughter of Phocas and [[Leontia]]. In 607, she married the general [[Priscus (general)|Priscus]], who served as ''[[comes excubitorum]]'', commander of the [[Excubitors]] bodyguard.<ref name=PLRE409/> As she was the only known child of the Emperor, the marriage effectively made Priscus an [[heir apparent]] to the throne. Her husband fell into disfavour however when the citizenry of [[Constantinople]] began erecting statues in their honour.<ref name=PLRE1056>Martindale, Jones & Morris (1992), p. 1056</ref>
Her marriage took place in the palace of Marina, named after its original owner, a daughter of [[Arcadius]] and [[Aelia Eudoxia]]. A [[chariot racing]] event was arranged to be held in the [[Hippodrome of Constantinople]], in honor of the newlyweds. The leaders of the Blues (''Vénetoi'') and the Greens (''Prásinoi'') racing factions (''demoi'') decided to honor the occasion by erecting statues of the royal family. Thus they placed images of Phocas, Leontia, Domentzia, and Priscus in the Hippodrome. The images of the reigning imperial couple belonged there by tradition, but the latter two implied that Priscus was the heir or co-emperor of Phocas. Phocas was enraged at the implication and ordered the depictions of his daughter and son-in-law to be destroyed.<ref name=Bury202>Bury (2009), p. 202</ref>
Phocas further treated the matter as an attempted [[coup d'état]], demanding further investigation of the matter, arresting the demarchs responsible with accusations of [[treason]]. While their lives may have been spared due to popular demand, Phocas likely viewed Priscus himself as the culprit, and seems to have started viewing his son-in-law as a potential rival.<ref name=Bury202/> By alienating Priscus however, Phocas undermined his own hold on the throne. By 608, John of Antioch reports Priscus initiating contact with [[Heraclius the Elder]], the [[Exarchate of Africa|Exarch of Africa]], and instigating the revolt that would eventually remove Phocas from power.<ref name=Bury202-203>Bury (2009), pp. 202–203</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
== Sources == * {{cite book | last=Bury | first=John Bagnell | authorlink=J.B. Bury | title=History of the Later Roman Empire from Arcadius to Irene| volume=II | year=2009 | origyear=1889 | publisher=Cosimo, Inc. | isbn=1-60520-405-6 }} * {{citation | last=Martindale | first=John R. | last2=Jones | first2=A.H.M. | last3=Morris | first3=John | title=The Prosopography of the Later Roman Empire - Volume III, AD 527–641 | year=1992 | publisher=Cambridge University Press | isbn=0-521-20160-8 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fBImqkpzQPsC}}

{{multiple image|total_width=650 |title= The Eight Witnesses |caption_align=center|footer_align=center |width1= 500|height1=598|image1=Hyrum Smith ca 1880-1920.png|caption1=[[Hyrum Smith]] |width2=923|height2=1277|image2=Joseph Smith, Sr.jpg|caption2=[[Joseph Smith, Sr]] |width3=276|height3= 315|image3=Samuel H. Smith.jpg|caption3=[[Samuel H. Smith (Latter Day Saints)|Samuel H. Smith]] |width4= 327|height4= 414|image4=Jacob Whitmer.jpg|caption4=[[Jacob Whitmer]] |width5=237|height5=300|image5=John Whitmer.jpg|caption5=[[John Whitmer]] |footer=(not shown: [[Hiram Page]], [[Christian Whitmer]], and [[Peter Whitmer, Jr.]]) }} The '''Eight Witnesses''' were one of the two groups of witnesses who made a statement stating that they had seen the [[golden plates]] which [[Joseph Smith]], Jr. said was his source material for the [[Book of Mormon]]. The other group of [[Book of Mormon witnesses]] who said they saw the plates are called the [[Three Witnesses]]. ==Testimony== The testimony of the Eight Witnesses was first published at the end of the 1830 edition of the Book of Mormon and has been printed in nearly every edition since, although most subsequent editions moved the statement to the front of the book and included minor grammatical corrections.
Be it known unto all nations, kindreds, tongues, and people, unto whom this work shall come: That Joseph Smith, Jun., the translator of this work, has shewn unto us the plates of which hath been spoken, which have the appearance of gold; and as many of the leaves as the said Smith has translated we did handle with our hands; and we also saw the engravings thereon, all of which has the appearance of ancient work, and of curious workmanship. And this we bear record with words of soberness, that the said Smith has shewn unto us, for we have seen and hefted, and know of a surety that the said Smith has got the plates of which we have spoken. And we give our names unto the world, to witness unto the world that which we have seen. And we lie not, God bearing witness of it. [[File:The signatures of the Eight Witnesses to the Book of Mormon.jpg|thumb|Photograph of the signatures of the Eight Witnesses to the Book of Mormon]] Christian Whitmer Jacob Whitmer Peter Whitmer, Jun. John Whitmer Hiram Page Joseph Smith, Sen. Hyrum Smith Samuel H. Smith
Unlike the Three Witnesses, the Eight testified that they both saw and handled the plates. Another difference is that the Eight testified that they were shown the plates by [[Joseph Smith]] rather than by an angel as had the Three Witnesses.According to Terryl Givens, Joseph invited the Eight "to a family prayer spot in the woods" and "matter-of-factly displayed to them the golden plates," whereas the Three were shown the plates "by an angel of God [who] came down from heaven." [[Terryl Givens]], ''By the Hand of Mormon'' (Oxford University Press, 2002), 40. ==Setting== Toward the end of June 1829, at the [[Peter Whitmer, Sr.]] home in [[Fayette, New York]], Joseph Smith, Jr. (with [[Oliver Cowdery]] as scribe) finished the translation of the Book of Mormon. Near the end of translation process, a prophecy was translated from the [[Second Book of Nephi]] that three, and "a few" others, might see the golden plates. Subsequently, on June 28, 1829, near the Whitmer farm,{{citation |first= Gale Yancey |last= Anderson |date=Spring 2012 |title= Eleven Witnesses Behold the Plates |journal= [[Journal of Mormon History]] |volume= 38 |issue= 2}}{{rp|152}} the Three Witnesses had their experience. Thereafter, the Smith and Whitmer families traveled to the [[Joseph Smith, Sr.]] home in [[Palmyra (town), New York|Palmyra, New York]]. On July 2, 1829, near the Smith home, the Eight Witnesses saw and handled the golden plates.{{rp|156}} ==About the witnesses== The Eight Witnesses were all members of the Whitmer or Smith families: [[Christian Whitmer]], [[Jacob Whitmer]], [[Peter Whitmer, Jr.]], [[John Whitmer]], [[Hiram Page]], [[Joseph Smith, Sr.]], [[Hyrum Smith]], and [[Samuel H. Smith (Latter Day Saints)|Samuel H. Smith]]. Joseph Smith, Sr. was Joseph Smith's father, and Hyrum and Samuel were his brothers. Christian, Jacob, Peter Jr. and John were [[David Whitmer]]'s brothers, and Hiram Page was his brother-in-law.[[Richard Lyman Bushman]], ''[[Joseph Smith: Rough Stone Rolling]]'' (New York: Alfred A. Knopf, 2005) p. 79: "Critics pointed out how many of the witnesses were members of the Smith and Whitmer families, implying that they signed out of loyalty or from a self-serving motive .... The witnesses were no substitute for making the plates accessible to anyone for examination, but the testimonies showed Joseph—and God—answering doubters with concrete evidence, a concession to the needs of post-Enlightenment Christians." Noting the familiar relationship among the witnesses, satirist [[Mark Twain]] wrote, "I could not feel more satisfied and at rest if the entire Whitmer family had testified."https://books.google.com/books?id=y589pE4d9FcC&pg=PA113 ===Split with Smith=== In 1838, the living members of Whitmer family (Christian Whitmer and Peter Whitmer, Jr. died in 1835 and 1836, respectively) became estranged from Smith during a leadership struggle in [[Far West, Missouri]], and all were excommunicated along with other dissenters and fled Caldwell County after receiving an ultimatum from the [[Danites]].Bushman, 337, 339, 350–51. On June 17, [[Sidney Rigdon]] "preached [[Salt sermon|a vitriolic sermon]] based on the theme of salt losing its savor and being cast out and trodden underfoot .... Soon after the sermon, eighty-three prominent members in Far West, many of them probably Danites by then, signed an ultimatum demanding the departure of the offenders .... Fearing for their property and perhaps their lives, the dissenters fled." (355–51) In 1847, David, John, and Jacob Whitmer and Hiram Page were baptized into the newly formed [[Church of Christ (Whitmerite)|Church of Christ]] founded by [[William E. M'Lellin]]. In 1831, Joseph Smith received a revelation from God that John Whitmer should "write and keep a regular history" of the church (D&C 47). Whitmer did eventually write such a history, but one which concluded with a detailed description of what Whitmer considered the mistreatment that he and his family had received in Caldwell County. See Bruce N. Westerngren, ''From Historian to Dissident: The Book of John Whitmer'' (Salt Lake City: Signature Books, 1995). Following the death of Smith, none of the Whitmers joined the group that was led by [[Brigham Young]] and would become [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]]. Yet despite the estrangement of the Whitmer family, there is little evidence that any of the Eight Witnesses denied his testimony to the authenticity of Book of Mormon or the gold plates.{{Citation |last=Givens |first=Terryl |title=The Book of Mormon: A Very Short Introduction |year=2009 |publisher=Oxford University Press |page=99}}; {{Citation |last=Remini |first=Robert |title=Joseph Smith |year=2002 |publisher=Penguin Group |pages=67–68}}. One third-hand source, the former Mormon leader Stephen Burnett, said in 1838 that [[Martin Harris (Latter Day Saints)|Martin Harris]] had told him that "the eight witnesses never saw [the plates] & hesitated to sign that instrument for that reason, but were persuaded to do it." Stephen Burnett letter to Lyman E. Johnson dated April 15, 1838. Typed transcript from Joseph Smith Papers, Letter book, April 20, 1837 – February 9, 1843, microfilm reel 2, pp. 64–66, LDS Church archives ==See also== {{Wikipedia books |1=Book of Mormon witnesses }} {{Portal|Book of Mormon|LDS Church}} *[[Mary Whitmer]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{citation |contribution-url= http://contentdm.lib.byu.edu/cdm/ref/collection/EoM/id/5554 |contribution= Book of Mormon Witnesses |first= Richard Lloyd |last= Anderson |pages= 214-216 |editor-last= Ludlow |editor-first= Daniel H |editor-link= Daniel H. Ludlow |year= 1992 |title= [[Encyclopedia of Mormonism]] |location= New York |publisher= [[Macmillan Publishing]] |isbn= 0-02-879602-0 |oclc= 24502140 }} ==External links== * [http://en.fairmormon.org/Three_Witnesses FAIR Mormon - Three Witnesses]- Apologetic bibliography and commentary. * [http://irr.org/mit/bom-wit-pt1.html Book of Mormon Witnesses, Part 1]; [https://web.archive.org/web/20081012073811/http://www.irr.org/mit/bom-wit-pt2.html The Book Of Mormon Witnesses, Part 2] - Critical commentary. {{Book of Mormon Witnesses}} [[Category:1829 in Christianity]] [[Category:1829 in New York (state)]] [[Category:1830 in Christianity]] [[Category:1830 in New York (state)]] [[Category:Articles about multiple people]] [[Category:Fayette, New York]] [[Category:Book of Mormon witnesses|8 witnesses]]

page.title: Flag of the President of Azerbaijan

revision.text:
[[File:Flag of the President of Azerbaijan.svg|thumb|219x219px|Presidential Standard of Azerbaijan]]The [[Presidential standard|Presidential Standard]] (Flag) of the Republic of Azerbaijan ({{Lang-az|Azərbaycan Respublikası Prezidentinin ştandartı (bayrağı)}}) is the official flag of the [[President of Azerbaijan]].
== History == The Flag of the President of Azerbaijan was confirmed by the decree №828 of the [[President of Azerbaijan]] on “The Standard (flag) of the President of the Republic of Azerbaijan” dated September 15, 2008.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://azertag.az/xeber/Sentyabrin_15_de_Prezident_Ilham_Aliyev_Azerbaycan_Respublikasi_Prezidentinin_standarti_bayragi_haqqinda_Ferman_imzalamisdir-418434|title=President of Azerbaijan signs Decree on Presidential Standard of the Republic of Azerbaijan|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=2018-04-19|archive-url=https://azertag.az/xeber/Sentyabrin_15_de_Prezident_Ilham_Aliyev_Azerbaycan_Respublikasi_Prezidentinin_standarti_bayragi_haqqinda_Ferman_imzalamisdir-418434|archive-date=2018-04-19|dead-url=|language=az}}</ref> The decree came into force on the same day of its issuance.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://e-qanun.az/alpidata/framework/data/15/f_15400.htm|title=Decree on the Presidential Standard of the Republic of Azerbaijan|last=|first=|date=|website=e-qanun.az|archive-url=http://e-qanun.az/alpidata/framework/data/15/f_15400.htm|archive-date=2018-04-19|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://files.preslib.az/projects/remz/pdf_en/remz_bayraq.pdf|title=Standard of the President of the Republic of Azerbaijan|last=|first=|date=|website=Administrative Department of the President of the Republic of Azerbaijan Presidential Library|archive-url=http://files.preslib.az/projects/remz/pdf_en/remz_bayraq.pdf|archive-date=2018-04-19|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref>
== Usage == [[File:Inauguration Ceremony 2013.jpg|thumb|Inauguration ceremony of the President of Azerbaijan with Flag of Azerbaijan (left) and Presidential Flag (right)]] According to the Decree, the Standard of the President of Azerbaijan is the official symbol of the [[President of Azerbaijan]]. The original version of the Presidential Standard is kept in the office of the President at the Presidential Palace. The duplicates of Presidential Flag can be placed, hung or raised on the buildings of Presidential Palace and Presidential residences; also can be placed in the halls or rooms of Presidential Palace or Presidential residences if any official event is intended to be conducted in the presence of the President; on other premises when the President of Azerbaijan is visiting; in the halls or on the building, where official or other types of events are being held with the participation of the [[President of Azerbaijan]]; and on the vehicles of the President.<ref name=":0" />
Presidential flag is also used during inaugural ceremony. It is brought onto the stage by the soldiers of the Armed Forces under the accompaniment of the ceremonial march during inauguration ceremony.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://en.president.az/articles/9667|title=Official inauguration of Ilham Aliyev 2013|last=|first=|date=|website=en.president.az|language=en|archive-url=https://en.president.az/articles/9667|archive-date=2018-04-19|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://azertag.az/xeber/XALQA_VATANA_VA_DOVLATA_SADAQAT_ANDI_AZARBAYCAN_RESPUBLIKASININ_PREZIDENTI_ILHAM_ALIYEVIN_ANDICHMA_MARASIMI-422046|title=Inauguration ceremony of the President of Azerbaijan (2008)|last=|first=|date=|work=AZERBAIJAN STATE NEWS AGENCY|access-date=2018-04-19|archive-url=https://azertag.az/xeber/XALQA_VATANA_VA_DOVLATA_SADAQAT_ANDI_AZARBAYCAN_RESPUBLIKASININ_PREZIDENTI_ILHAM_ALIYEVIN_ANDICHMA_MARASIMI-422046|archive-date=2018-04-19|dead-url=|language=az}}</ref>
== Design == The Presidential Flag is like a square version of the tricolor [[Flag of Azerbaijan|Azerbaijani flag]] with the [[National emblem of Azerbaijan|Coat of Arm of Azerbaijan]] on both sides of red stripe instead of white crescent and eight-pointed star. The Presidential Flag is framed with golden fringes.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
There is silver cord attached to the pole of the Presidential Flag illustrating the full name of the [[President of Azerbaijan]] and the date of his term of office. The pole of the flag is covered with a metal hood in crescent and 8 point star shape.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
== See also ==
* [[President of Azerbaijan]] * [[Flag of Azerbaijan]]
== References == <references />
== External links == * [https://en.president.az/ Official website of the President of Azerbaijan]
[[Category:Personal flags]] [[Category:National symbols of Azerbaijan]]

[[File:Hans Heiling.jpg|400px|right|thumb|Hans-Heiling-Felsen]] '''Hans Heiling''' (Jan Svatoš in [[Czech language|Czech]]) is a legendary person in [[Germany|German]] and [[Bohemia]]n mythology.
The stories originate from German inhabitants of [[Loket (Sokolov District)|Loket]] (now in the [[Czech Republic]]). The son of a water fairy from the river [[Ohře]], who taught him to master magic and command spirits. Once he had become rich and powerful, he ordered the spirits under his command to build a great city. The granite rocks above the Ohře, named [[Hans-Heiling-Felsen]] (Svatošské Skály in Czech), were believed to be the ruins of this city.<ref name="cz">[http://www.cot.cz/zobrazcl.php?id=5492 COT.cz tourism site] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011002443/http://www.cot.cz/zobrazcl.php?id=5492 |date=2007-10-11 }}</ref> When Hans Heiling discovered that he could not achieve human happiness even with his supernatural powers, he discarded them and died fighting a bear. Another variant of the story is that the rock formation is a [[Petrifaction in mythology and fiction|petrified]] wedding party. A notable [[opera]] of the [[Hans Heiling|same name]] was inspired by the tale.
The poem "Ballad", by [[Gerda Mayer]], is based on the wedding party variant and appears in The Oxford Book of Story Poems.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Oxford Book of Story Poems|year=1990|publisher=OUP|isbn=0 19 276087 4|pages=27–29|editor=Michael Harrison and Christopher Stuart-Clark}}</ref>
==References== <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hans Heiling (Mythology)}} [[Category:Czech mythology]] [[Category:Germanic mythology]] [[Category:Mythological characters]]
{{Europe-myth-stub}}

page.title: Jack of the President of the Republic of Poland

revision.text:
{{Infobox flag | Name = Jack of the President of the Republic of Poland | Image = Flag of the President of Poland.svg | Proportion = 5:6 | Adoption = 1996 | Design = Crowned [[Coat of arms of Poland|White Eagle]] in a red field bordered with a white wavy line }}
'''Jack of the President of the Republic of Poland – Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces of the Republic of Poland''' ({{lang-pl|proporzec Prezydenta Rzeczypospolitej Polskiej – Zwierzchnika Sił Zbrojnych Rzeczypospolitej Polskiej}}) is a [[Maritime flag#Jacks|jack flag]] used in the [[Polish Armed Forces]] to mark the presence and pay respect to the [[President of the Republic of Poland]] who is also ''ex officio'' the [[commander-in-chief]] of the Armed Forces. The jack is raised on [[Polish Navy]] ships when the president is officially on board, as well as on land, if the president is present. The design of the jack is based directly on the [[History of Poland (1918–1939)|pre-war]] [[Banner of Poland|Banner of the Republic of Poland]] which used to be part of presidential insignia.
== Legal specifications == [[File:Presidential jack unknown soldier.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Presidential jack flying at the [[Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Warsaw]] during a [[Constitution of May 3, 1791|Constitution Day]] ceremony]]
The jack of the President is defined in the Ordinance of the Minister of National Defense on the Use of Insignia of the Armed Forces of January 26, 1996 with subsequent amendments. The ordinance defines the jack of the President as "a piece of red cloth with the image of the state eagle (i.e. the White Eagle from the [[Coat of Arms of Poland|national coat of arms]]) in the middle, bordered with a ''wężyk generalski''", an ornate wavy line used in the Polish military as a symbol of [[generał|general's]] rank. The [[Hoist (flag)|hoist]] to [[Flag terminology#Description of standard flag parts and terms|fly]] ratio is 5:6. The proportion of the eagle's height to the fly is 3:5.<ref name=ordinance>{{pl icon}} ''Zarządzenie Ministra Obrony Narodowej z dnia 29 stycznia 1996 r. w sprawie szczegółowych zasad używania znaków Sił Zbrojnych Rzeczypospolitej Polskiej oraz ustalenia innych znaków używanych w Siłach Zbrojnych Rzeczypospolitej Polskiej'' ([http://www.abc.com.pl/serwis/mp/1996/0178.htm M.P.96.14.178] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930015219/http://www.abc.com.pl/serwis/mp/1996/0178.htm |date=2007-09-30 }})</ref>
== Usage ==
The presidential jack is used in military ceremonies attended by the commander-in-chief. Celebrations of the Constitution Day, May 3; Polish Armed Forces Day, August 15; and Independence Day, November 11 (see [[Public holidays in Poland]]) are typical occasions. For example, during the grand military parade on August 15, 2007 in [[Warsaw]], President [[Lech Kaczyński]] rode in a convertible jeep preceded by a mounted [[Polish cavalry|cavalry]] officer carrying the presidential jack,<ref>{{cite news | title = Tanks roll in Warsaw as Poles celebrate military victory | work = International Herald Tribune | date = 2007-08-15 | url = http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/08/15/europe/EU-GEN-Poland-Military-Parade.php | accessdate = 2007-08-19 }}</ref> while a smaller jack was attached to the president's jeep as a car flag. The jack also draped the coffins of President Kaczyński (see [[Death and state funeral of Lech Kaczyński and Maria Kaczyńska]]) and former President-in-exile [[Ryszard Kaczorowski]] after both died in the [[2010 Polish Air Force Tu-154 crash|Smolensk air crash]] of 2010.
== History == [[File:Banner of Poland.jpg|thumb|left|100px|Banner of the Republic on display in the [[Royal Castle in Warsaw]]]]
{{Main article|Banner of Poland}}
A state banner was used in Poland as insignia of the head of state (king, president, etc.) as early as the 11th century CE. Although its design changed with time, it was always a heraldic banner, i.e. one based directly on the national coat of arms: a crowned White Eagle in a red field. In 1919, the [[Sejm]] (lower house of parliament) established the [[Banner of the Republic of Poland]], reserved for use by the head of state – the State Leader (''[[Naczelnik Państwa]]'') and, later, President of the Republic. In 1927, it was modified to reflect the adoption of a new official rendering of the national coat of arms. At this point the banner was virtually identical to the current design for the presidential jack.<ref name=znamier>{{cite book | last = Znamierowski | first = Alfred | authorlink = | title = Stworzony do chwały | publisher = Editions Spotkania | year = 1995 | location = Warsaw | pages = 299 | isbn = 83-7115-055-5|language=pl}}</ref>
After the [[Second World War]], the Banner of the Republic was still used by [[Polish government-in-exile|presidents-in-exile]] while a variant with a crownless eagle was used by Communist authorities at home. Officially abandoned in 1955, the banner continued to be used in practice by the [[Prime Minister of the Republic of Poland|prime minister]] and, during the 1960s, by the [[Polish Council of State|Council of State]], a collective head of state of the time.<ref name=znamier/>
The modern Jack of the President of the Republic of Poland was established by the Minister of National Defense on January 29, 1996 with the sole purpose of flying it on Polish Navy ships while the commander-in-chief is on board.<ref name=ordinance/> On December 14, 2005, the use of the presidential jack was extended to all branches of Polish Armed Forces.<ref>{{pl icon}} ''Zarządzenie Ministra Obrony Narodowej z dnia 14 grudnia 2005 r. zmieniające zarządzenie w sprawie szczegółowych zasad używania znaków Sił Zbrojnych Rzeczypospolitej Polskiej oraz ustalenia innych znaków używanych w Siłach Zbrojnych Rzeczypospolitej Polskiej'' ([http://www.abc.com.pl/serwis/mp/2005/1165.htm M.P.05.82.1165] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930033325/http://www.abc.com.pl/serwis/mp/2005/1165.htm |date=2007-09-30 }})</ref> It was first flown on land during a Constitution Day ceremony at the [[Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Warsaw]] on May 3, 2005.
{{clear}}
== See also == [[File:Trumna Prezydenta Lecha Kaczyńskiego w Sali Kolumnowej Pałacu Prezydenckiego.jpg|thumb|right|President [[Lech Kaczyński]]'s coffin draped in the presidential jack while [[lying in state]]]]
* [[Banner of Poland]] * [[Flag of Poland]] * [[Coat of arms of Poland]] * [[President of the Republic of Poland]] * [[List of Polish flags]]

{{Infobox Chinese-language singer and actor | name = Jackie Chan Stunt Team | image = JackieChanLogo.jpg | chinesename = 成家班 | pinyinchinesename = Chéng Jiā Bān | jyutpingchinesename = Sing4 Gaa1 Baan1 | origin = [[Hong Kong]] | occupation = Actors, action directors, stuntmen | yearsactive = 1976–present | hongkongfilmwards = '''[[Hong Kong Film Award for Best Action Choreography|Best Action Choreography]]'''
1985 ''[[Project A]]''
1986 ''[[Police Story (1985 film)|Police Story]]''
1988 ''[[Project A Part II]]''
1989 ''[[Police Story 2]]''
1990 ''[[Miracles (1989 film)|Miracles]]''
1995 ''[[Drunken Master II]]''
2002 ''[[The Accidental Spy]]'' | goldenhorseawards = '''Best Action Choreography'''
1994 ''[[Drunken Master II]]''
1995 ''[[Thunderbolt (1995 film)|Thunderbolt]]''
1997 ''[[Mr. Nice Guy (1997 film)|Mr. Nice Guy]]''
1998 ''[[Who Am I? (1998 film)|Who Am I?]]''
2004 ''[[New Police Story]]'' }} The '''Jackie Chan Stunt Team''' ({{zh|t=成家班|cy=Sing Ga Ban|l=Chan's Family Group}}), also known as '''Jackie Chan's Stuntmen Association''' is a group of [[stunt double|stuntmen]] and [[martial arts|martial artists]] who work alongside [[Jackie Chan]]. ==History== The JC Stunt Team was established in 1976 and originated from the relationships Chan formed in his early starring roles in [[Hong Kong action cinema|Hong Kong action movies]]. Several of his co-stars and stuntmen hired by the [[movie studio|film studios]] began working together regularly. This engendered a familiarity of one another's skills and abilities and it made sense for them to become a working team. Some of the members had received training at the [[Peking Opera school]]s, similar to Chan. By 1983, and the release of the film ''[[Project A]]'', the stunt team had become an official organisation of 6 members. The organisation meant that the stuntmen not only received [[Insurance|insurance coverage]], but also a monthly salary and higher pay. By the time of ''[[Police Story 2]]'' in 1988, the team had expanded to around 20 members. This incarnation of the team was disbanded in 1990 and thereafter, individual members were contracted and used on a film-by-film basis rather than all members remaining on the payroll.{{cite book | title = The Unauthorised Jackie Chan Encyclopedia | last = Corcoran | first = John | coauthors = | authorlink= | year = 2002 | publisher= McGraw Hill | location= New York | isbn= 978-0-07-138899-3 | page= | pages= }} This allowed for some new faces, and the return of former members. The formation of Chan's team influenced others in the [[Film industry|business]] to follow suit, particularly his former co-stars and "brothers" [[Sammo Hung]] and [[Yuen Biao]] (their stunt teams known as "Hung Ga Ban" and "Yuen Ga Ban" respectively). Other actors who formed their own stunt teams include [[Lau Kar-leung]], [[Philip Ko]], [[Stanley Tong]] and [[Bruce Law]]. Chan's stunt team worked in collaboration with Sammo Hung's team on films including [[Thunderbolt (1995 film)|Thunderbolt]] and [[Around the World in 80 Days (2004 film)|Around the World in 80 Days]]. A small number of films that Chan produced but did not appear in, or was not involved in at all, have utilised his stunt team. These include ''The Gold Hunters'' (1981), ''[[Rouge (film)|Rouge]]'' (1988), ''The Inspector Wears Skirts 2'' (1989), ''Stage Door Johnny'' (1990) and ''Angry Ranger'' (1991).{{cite web | title = HKCinemagic | work = Sing Ga Ban | url=http://www.hkcinemagic.com/en/people.asp?id=2393 | accessdate = 2009-01-17 }} ==Members (past & present)== These are former and current members of Chan's stunt team. Where possible'', ''the films they have worked on are included: * '''[[Michael Tse]]''' – * '''Andy Kay''' – * '''Colin Flora''' – ''[[Rumble in the Bronx]]'', ''[[Rush Hour 2]]'' * '''[[Brad Allan]]''' (Bradley James Allan) – ''[[Mr. Nice Guy (1997 film)|Mr. Nice Guy]]'', ''[[Who Am I? (1998 film)|Who Am I?]]'', ''[[Jackie Chan: My Stunts]]'', ''[[Gorgeous (film)|Gorgeous]]'', ''[[Shanghai Noon]]'', ''[[The Accidental Spy]]'', ''Rush Hour 2'', ''[[The Tuxedo]]'', ''[[Shanghai Knights]]'', ''[[The Medallion]]'', ''[[New Police Story]]'', ''[[Rush Hour 3]]'', ''[[Chinese Zodiac (film)|Armour Of God 3: Chinese Zodiac]]. revision.text:
'''Keaweaweʻulaokalani''' is a name shared by two short-lived princes and heirs to the throne of the [[Kingdom of Hawaii]]. Both were named after their father [[Kamehameha III]]. In [[Hawaiian language|Hawaiian]], the name means "the red trail of heaven", signifying the roadway by which the god descends from heaven.
==Earlier== {{Infobox royalty | name = Keaweaweʻulaokalani I | title = Prince of Hawaii | house = [[House of Kamehameha]] | father = [[Kamehameha III]] | mother = [[Kalama]] | birth_date = 1839 | birth_place = | death_date = 1839 | death_place = |}} '''Keaweaweʻulaokalani I''' (1839–1839) was the eldest son of [[Kamehameha III]] and his queen consort [[Kalama Hakaleleponi-i-Kapakuhaili]]. The baby boy was named after his father whose full name was Keaweawe{{okina}}ula Kiwala{{okina}}o Kauikeaouli Kaleiopapa Kalani Waiakua Kalanikau Iokikilo Kiwala{{okina}}o i ke kapu Kamehameha. The royal suffix o-Kalani was added in to signified this Prince of [[Heaven]].
The young Prince Keawe died shortly after his birth. His death left Kamehameha III again childless. His younger brother, Keaweaweʻulaokalani II, would not be born until 1842.
==Later== {{Infobox royalty | name = Keaweaweʻulaokalani II | title = Prince of Hawaii | house = [[House of Kamehameha]] | father = [[Kamehameha III]] | mother = [[Kalama]] | birth_date = January 14, 1842 | birth_place = | death_date = February 1842 | death_place = |}} '''Keaweaweʻulaokalani II''' (1842–1842) was the second son of [[Kamehameha III]] and his queen consort [[Kalama Hakaleleponi-i-Kapakuhaili]]. The baby boy was the namesake of his father and his brother.
Initially given in ''[[hānai]]'' to [[Kalākua Kaheiheimālie]], he was instead adopted or ''hānai'' by his grand aunt, [[Kekāuluohi]] and her husband [[Charles Kanaina|Kana{{okina}}ina]] when the old governess of Maui died not three days after his birth. The King promised that he would be sent to the [[Chiefs' Children's School]] once he was weaned and could walk. He soon developed a fever and died, at the age of only 31 days. Dr. Baldwin of Lahaina was convinced that the child was killed by traditional medicinal treatment.
==Family tree== {{Kamehameha family tree}}
==References== * {{cite web |url= http://www.royalark.net/Hawaii/hawaii7.htm |title=The Kamehameha Dynasty Genealogy (Page 7) |author=Christopher Buyers |accessdate=February 26, 2012 |work= Royal Ark web site }} * {{cite book|last=Kamakau|first=Samuel|authorlink=Samuel Kamakau|title=Ruling Chiefs of Hawaii|url=http://www.ulukau.org/elib/cgi-bin/library?c=chiefs&l=en|edition=Revised|year=1992|origyear=1961|publisher=[[Kamehameha Schools]] Press|location=Honolulu|isbn=0-87336-014-1|pages=264, 342, 388, 395}} * {{cite book |title= Speeches of His Majesty Kamehameha III: to the Hawaiian Legislature |author= [[Kamehameha III]] |page= 10 |publisher= Government Press |year=1861 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=1U8gU7VqaY4C }} * {{cite book |chapter= Reality and Fantasy: The Foster Child in Hawaiian Myths and Customs |author= Katharine Luomala, University of Hawaii |title= Pacific Studies |year= 1987 |publisher= Brigham Young University Hawaii Campus |pages= 26 |url= https://ojs.lib.byu.edu/spc/index.php/PacificStudies/article/viewFile/9449/9098 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160304191704/https://ojs.lib.byu.edu/spc/index.php/PacificStudies/article/viewFile/9449/9098 |archivedate= 2016-03-04 |df= }} * {{cite book |title= The Hawaiian Chiefs' Children's School |author= [[Amos Starr Cooke]], Juliette Montague Cooke |editor=Mary Atherton Richards |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=kHBBAAAAIAAJ |publisher= C. E. Tuttle Company |page=126| origyear= 1937 |year= 1970}} * {{cite book |url= https://books.google.com/books?ei=t1NwT_6OJ5DKiAKB66i8BQ&id=HitzAAAAMAAJ |title= Moku'ula: Maui's sacred island |author= P. Christiaan Klieger |year= 1998 |publisher= [[Bishop Museum]] Press |location= Honolulu |isbn= 1-58178-002-8 |pages=53–54, 82}}

revision.comment: Undid revision 859015093 by [[Special:Contributions/Hugohmp93|Hugohmp93]] ([[User talk:Hugohmp93|talk]]); not an improvement
revision.text:
'''Legal biography''' is the [[biography]] of persons relevant to [[law]]. In a preface dated October 1983, [[A. W. B. Simpson]] wrote that it was "a rather neglected field".<ref>A W B Simpson (editor). [[Biographical Dictionary of the Common Law]]. Butterworths. London. 1984. {{ISBN|0 406 51657 X}}. Page v</ref> Since then there as been a "resurgence of interest".<ref>Parry, R Gwynedd. Is Legal Biography Really Legal Scholarship? (June 2010) Legal Studies: The Journal of the [[Society of Legal Scholars]]. Volume 30. Issue 2. Page 208. Wiley Online Library. {{doi|10.1111/j.1748-121X.2009.00149.x}}</ref>
==See also== * ''[[Biographia Juridica]]''
==References== ;Notes {{reflist}} ;Bibliography *[http://www.lse.ac.uk/collections/law/projects/legalbiog/lbp.htm Legal Biography Project]. [[London School of Economics]], Department of Law. *Fenster, Mark. "The Folklore of Legal Biography" (2007) 105 [[Michigan Law Review]] 1265. [http://scholarship.law.ufl.edu/facultypub/47 University of Florida]. *[[Henry Roscoe (legal writer)|Henry]] and [[Thomas Roscoe]] (compilers). "Legal Biography" in ''Westminster Hall: or Professional Relics and Anectdotes of the Bar, Bench and Woolsack''. John Knight & Henry Lacey. London. 1825. Volume 3. Pages 209–226. [https://books.google.com/books?id=RmlHAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA209#v=onepage&q&f=false Digitized copy] from [[Google Books]]. *Association of American Law Schools. "Reading and Writing Legal Biography" in 1977 Annual Meeting Proceedings. 1977. Part One. Page 23. [https://books.google.com/books?id=oyM7AQAAIAAJ Snippet view] from Google Books. *Maxwell and Maxwell. [[A Legal Bibliography of the British Commonwealth of Nations]]. Sweet & Maxwell. London. 1955. Volume 1: English Law to 1800. Chapter 26 ("Biography"). *"Historical value of legal biography" (1909) 29 Canadian Law Times 450 *Nelson and Reid. "Legal Biography" in ''The Literature of American Legal History''. Oceana Publications Inc. 1985. Reprinted by Beard Books. 2006. [https://books.google.com/books?id=B0SVHOxcYF0C&pg=PA58 p 58]. *2 [[Hoffman's Course of Legal Study]] [https://books.google.com/books?id=t3k8AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA622#v=onepage&q&f=false 622]
[[Category:Legal professions]] [[Category:Biography (genre)]]

{{original research|date=July 2017}} These mythological monarchs supposedly ruled Fib, the reigns of these monarchs are mostly legendary and begin in the 7th century BCE with king Fib. The reigns of these monarchs are attributed to the Pictish chronicles, written in the 10th century during the reign of King Kenneth II of Scotland.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://anthonyadolph.co.uk/the-pictish-king-list/|title=Pictish King List|website=anthonyadolph.co.uk|language=en-US|access-date=2017-07-09}}</ref>
==7th-4th Century BCE== {| class="wikitable" !Name !Ruled |- |[[King Fib|Fib or Fibaid]] |[[Kingdom of Fib]] |- |[[Gede-olgudach]] |[[Scone, Perth and Kinross|Scone]] |- |[[Denbecan]] | [[Celts|Celtic People]] |- |[[Oflinecta]] |[[Celts|Celtic People]] |- |[[Guidid-gaed-brechach]] |[[Celts]] |- |[[Gest-gurgich]]
|[[Celts]] |- |[[Wurgest]] |[[Celts]] |}
==4th Century CE (Pictish Kings)== {| class="wikitable" !Name !Reign !Short name !Ruled |- |[[Gartnait Ioc|Gartnait Ioc I]] |296-305 CE |[[Gartnait Ioc|Gartnait I]] |[[Pictland]] |- |[[Breth of Pictland|Breth]] |305-312 CE |[[Breth of Pictland|Breth]] |[[Pictland]] |} For later monarchs see [[List of Pictish kings|List of Pictish Kings]]. Fib became a puppet state after the reign of the only true king Fib, it was a sub-kingdom from the 7th century BCE until the 9th Century CE (691 BCE - 837/843 CE) when Pictland was united under Kenneth MacAlpin, the last king to rule Pictland before Kenneth was Drest X thus making him the last king of the Fib puppet-state.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kjhskj75z.talktalk.net/pictish.html|title=THE PICTISH CHRONICLE|website=www.kjhskj75z.talktalk.net|access-date=2017-07-09}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of Pictish kings]] * [[List of Scottish monarchs]] * [[Kingdom of Fib]] * [[King Fib]] * [[Fife]] * [[Pictland]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

page.title: List of personal coats of arms of Vice Presidents of the United States

revision.text:
Several [[United States]] [[Vice President of the United States|vice presidents]] have borne a [[coat of arms]]; largely through inheritance, assumption, or grants from foreign [[heraldic authority|heraldic authorities]].
==Arms of the Vice Presidents== {| class=wikitable |- style="vertical-align:top; text-align:center;" ! style="width:206px;"| Arms ! Name of Vice President and Blazon |- valign=top |align=center| [[File:Coat of Arms of John Adams.svg|100px]] |Arms of [[John Adams]], 1st Vice President, 1789–1797:
'''Shield:''' Gules six crosses-crosslet fitchy Argent, on a chief Or three pellets, the center one charged with a fleur-de-lys and the other two with lions passant guardant Argent.
'''Crest:''' A Lion passant holding in his dexter paw a cross-crosslet fitchy Argent.
'''Motto:''' ''Libertatem amicitiam retinebis et fidem'' (Freedom, friendship and fidelity).<ref name="Signers of the Declaration">[http://www.americanheraldry.org/pages/index.php?n=Notable.Declaration Signers of the Declaration of Independence] American Heraldry Society's Website</ref>
|- valign=top |align=center| [[File:Coat of Arms of Thomas Jefferson.svg|100px]] |Arms of [[Thomas Jefferson]], 2nd Vice President, 1797–1801:
'''Shield:''' Azure a fret and on a chief Gules three leopards' faces Argent
'''Crest:''' A lion's head erased Or.
'''Motto:''' ''Ab eo libertas a quo spiritus'' (The one who gives life gives liberty).<ref name="Signers of the Declaration" />
|- valign=top |align=center | |[[Aaron Burr]], 3rd Vice President, 1801–1805:
No arms known
|- valign=top |align=center| [[File:Coat of Arms of George Clinton.svg|100px]] |Arms of [[George Clinton (vice president)|George Clinton]], 4th Vice President, 1805–1812:
'''Shield:''' Argent, six cross crosslets fitchy Sable on a chief Azure two mullets Or pierced Gules
'''Crest:''' Out of a ducal coronet Gules a plume of five ostrich feathers Argent banded by a ribbon Azure
'''Motto:''' ''Cara patria, carior libertas'' (Dear fatherland, dearer freedom)
|- valign=top |align=center | |[[Elbridge Gerry]], 5th Vice President, 1813–1814:
No arms known
|- valign=top |align=center| [[File:Coat of Arms of Daniel D. Tompkins.svg|100px]] |Arms of [[Daniel D. Tompkins]], 6th Vice President, 1817–1825:
'''Shield:''' Azure, on a chevron between three cock-pheasants close Or three cross-crosslets Sable
'''Crest:''' A unicorn's head, erased, per fess, Argent and Or, armed and maned, counterchanged, gorged with a chaplet of laurel, Vert.
|- valign=top |align=center| [[File:Coat of Arms of John C. Calhoun.svg|100px]] |Arms of [[John C. Calhoun]], 7th Vice President, 1825–1832:
'''Shield:''' Argent, a saltire engrailed Sable
'''Crest:''' A hart's head couped Gules attired Argent
'''Supporters:''' Two ratch-hounds Argent, collared Sable
'''Motto:''' ''Si je puis'' (If I may)
|- valign=top |align=center| [[File:Coat of Arms of Martin Van Buren.svg|100px]] |Arms of [[Martin van Buren]], 8th Vice President, 1833–1837:
'''Shield:''' Per pale, Or a greyhound rampant contourny Gules, and Gules two bars embattled-counterembattled Or
'''Crest:''' A greyhound rampant between the wings of a vol Gules and Or.<ref>[http://www.americanheraldry.org/pages/index.php?n=President.VanBuren The Arms of Martin Van Buren] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120321032529/http://www.americanheraldry.org/pages/index.php?n=President.VanBuren |date=2012-03-21 }} American Heraldry Society's Website</ref>
|- valign=top |align=center | | [[Richard Mentor Johnson]], 9th Vice President, 1837–1841:
No arms known
|- valign=top |align=center | |[[John Tyler]], 10th Vice President, 1841:
No arms known
|- valign=top |align=center | |[[George M. Dallas]], 11th Vice President, 1845–1849:
No arms known
|- valign=top |align=center | | [[Millard Fillmore]], 12th Vice President, 1849–1850:
No arms known
|- valign=top |align=center | |[[William R. King]], 13th Vice President, 1853:
No arms known
|- valign=top |align=center | |[[John C. Breckinridge]], 14th Vice President, 1857–1861:
No arms known
|- valign=top |align=center | |[[Hannibal Hamlin]], 15th Vice President, 1861–1865:
No arms known
|- valign=top |align=center | |[[Andrew Johnson]], 16th Vice President, 1865:
No arms known
|- valign=top |align=center | |[[Schuyler Colfax]], 17th Vice President, 1869–1873:
No arms known
|- valign=top |align=center | |[[Henry Wilson]], 18th Vice President, 1873–1875:
No arms known
|- valign=top |align=center | |[[William A. Wheeler]], 19th Vice President, 1877–1881:
No arms known
|- valign=top |align=center| [[File:Coat of Arms of Chester A. Arthur.svg|100px]] |Arms of [[Chester A. Arthur]], 20th Vice President, 1881:
'''Shield:''' Gules a chevron Argent between three rests (clarions) Or.
'''Crest:''' A falcon rising proper belled and jessed Or.
'''Motto:''' ''Impelle obstantia'' (Thrust aside obstacles).<ref>[http://www.americanheraldry.org/pages/index.php?n=President.Arthur The Arms Used by Chester A. Arthur] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150218032644/http://www.americanheraldry.org/pages/index.php?n=President.Arthur |date=2015-02-18 }} American Heraldry Society's Website</ref>
|- valign=top |align=center | |[[Thomas A. Hendricks]], 21st Vice President, 1885:
No Arms known
|- valign=top |align=center | |[[Levi P. Morton]], 22nd Vice President, 1889–1893:
No arms known
|- valign=top |align=center | |[[Adlai Stevenson I]], 23rd Vice President, 1893–1897
No arms known
|- valign=top |align=center | |[[Garret Hobart]], 24th Vice President, 1897–1899:
No arms known
|- valign=top |align=center| [[File:Coat of Arms of Theodore Roosevelt.svg|100px]] |Arms of [[Theodore Roosevelt]], 25th Vice President, 1901:
'''Shield:''' Argent upon a grassy mound a rose bush proper bearing three roses Gules barbed and seeded proper
'''Crest:''' From a wreath Argent and Gules three ostrich plumes each per pale Gules and Argent
'''Motto:''' ''Qui plantavit curabit'' (He who planted will preserve).<ref>[http://www.americanheraldry.org/pages/index.php?n=President.Roosevelt The Arms of Theodore Roosevelt] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081230095848/http://americanheraldry.org/pages/index.php?n=President.Roosevelt |date=2008-12-30 }} American Heraldry Society's Website</ref>
|- valign=top |align=center | | [[Charles W. Fairbanks]], 26th Vice President, 1905–1909:
No known arms
|- valign=top |align=center| [[File:Coat of Arms of James S. Sherman.svg|100px]] |Arms of [[James S. Sherman]], 27th Vice President, 1909–1912:
'''Shield:''' Or, a Lion rampant Sable between three oak leaves Vert
'''Crest:''' A sea lion, sejant Sable charged on the shoulder with three bezants, two and one
|- valign=top |align=center | |[[Thomas R. Marshall]], 28th Vice President, 1913–1921:
No arms known
|- valign=top |align=center| [[File:Coat of Arms of Calvin Coolidge.svg|100px]] |Arms of [[Calvin Coolidge]], 29th Vice President, 1921–1923:
'''Shield:''' Vert a griffin segreant Or.
'''Crest:''' A demi-griffin segreant Or.
'''Motto:''' ''Virtute et fide'' (By valor and faith)
|- valign=top |align=center | |[[Charles G. Dawes]], 30th Vice President, 1925–1929:
No arms known
|- valign=top |align=center | |[[Charles Curtis]], 31st Vice President, 1929–1933:
No arms known
|- valign=top |align=center | |[[John Nance Garner]], 32nd Vice President, 1933–1941:
No arms known
|- valign=top |align=center | |[[Henry A. Wallace]], 33rd Vice President, 1941–1945:
No arms known
|- valign=top |align=center | |[[Harry S. Truman]], 34th Vice President, 1945:
No arms known
|- valign=top |align=center | | [[Alben W. Barkley]], 35th Vice President, 1949–1953
No arms known
|- valign=top |align=center | | Arms of [[Richard Nixon]], 36th Vice President, 1953–1961:
No known arms
|- valign=top |align=center| [[File:Coat of Arms of Lyndon B. Johnson.svg|100px]] | Arms of [[Lyndon Johnson]], 37th Vice President, 1961–1963:
'''Shield:''' Azure on a saltire Gules fimbriated Argent between four eagles displayed a mullet Or.
'''Crest:''' On a wreath of the colors an armed hand Argent supporting an eagle rising Or.
'''Motto:''' ''Nobilitatis virtus non stemma character'' (Virtue, not lineage, is the mark of nobility)
|- valign=top | |align=center| | [[Hubert Humphrey]], 38th Vice President, 1965–1969:
No arms known
|- valign=top | |align=center| [[File:Coat of Arms of Spiro Agnew.svg|100px]] | Arms of [[Spiro Agnew]], 39th Vice President, 1969–1973:
'''Shield:''' Azure, on a cross between four horses' heads couped Argent, a cross botonny Gules
'''Crest:''' A hand couped proper holding a sceptre of office
'''Supporters:''' Dexter a Greek statesman and sinister a Greek warrior both proper.
'''Motto:''' Do all good
|- valign=top |align=center | | [[Gerald Ford]], 40th Vice President, 1973–1974:
No arms known
|- valign=top |align=center | |[[Nelson Rockefeller]], 41st Vice President, 1974–1977:
No arms known
|- valign=top |align=center |
| [[Walter Mondale]], 42nd Vice President, 1977–1981:
No arms known
|- valign=top |align=center | | [[George H.W. Bush]], 43rd Vice President, 1981–1989:
No arms known

No arms known
